# Current

Current is the Rate of flow of [electric charge](electric-charge) (in [ampere](20220408110016-ampere.md)), and [electric current](20220418134607-electric-current.md) flows when [Electron](20220408114349-electron.md) move through a [conductor](20220408103508-conductor.md).

unit:: amperes (A)

<!--SR:!2022-04-26,4,270-->

symbol:: I

<!--SR:!2022-04-26,4,270-->

The direction of [current flow](20220408110703-current-flow.md) ($I>0$) is _opposing the flow of electrons_.

![49931a73151208023ace82229dd7c23b](data:image/png;base64,)

## Calculations

$$I=\frac{\Delta q}{\Delta t}$$
$$\text{current (A)}=\frac{\text{charge (C)}}{\text{time (s)}}$$

Note: electron has charge of $e=1.6\times 10^{-19}C$
$$I=\frac{\text{number of electrons}\times e}{\Delta t}$$

## Example

> What is the current if $20$C of charge passes in $5$s?

$$
\begin{align*}
I&=\frac{\Delta q}{\Delta t}\\
&=\frac{20}{5}=4 A
\end{align*}
$$

> An electric heater operated from a [DC source](20220221163300-dc-source.md) that provides $8.2\times 10^{21}$ electrons in $10$ seconds. How much current in amperes (A) is flowing through the heater?

$$I=\frac{\Delta q}{\Delta t}=\frac{1.6\times 10^{-19} C \times 8.2\times 10^{21}}{10 s}  = 131.2A$$

> If a [battery](20220221170305-battery.md) delivers a current of $50A$ when the car is started, and the starting time is $4$ seconds, how many electrons flow out of the battery?

$$
\begin{align*}
I&=\frac{\Delta q}{\Delta t}\\
50A&=\frac{1.6\times 10^{-19}C\times n}{4s}\\
n&=\frac{50A\times 4s}{1.6\times 10^{-19}C}\\
&=1.25\times 10^{21}
\end{align*}
$$

## Background

1. Current was originally defined as the flow of charges from +ve from -ve.
2. Scientists later discovered that current is actually the flow of -ve-ly charged electron (from -ve to +ve)
3. Then the originally definition (bullet point 1), has been renamed to [conventional current](Conventional-Current).
